channel.title: A bot in C#?
channel.description:
Weird question, from what I've read I don't think that it's possible to do this but most people here know a whole lot more then I do.
Would it be possible to load the RuneScape client into a C# Form? And I don't mean just opening the webpage that has the client on it. If that makes any sense..

SMART is open source nowadays, https://github.com/BenLand100/SMART/tree/master/src

Coded in C++ and Java, though. If you were planning on a nice sunday project to practice some pure C#, scrap it and make a conventional Java bot (I have no idea why do people insist on shitting out a new one on a daily basis).

item.title: A bot in C#?
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“chri5, post:12, topic:398386”]What would be the best way to do this? it seems that “scionbot” use a client/server socket shit (not sure if I read it correctly, remember I am an idiot) which seems like it’d work but is a bad hack.

Something like SMART?[/quote]I’m not sure how SMART works, but I’d say something like running an instance of the client, getting the canvas’ window handle (HWND), and sub-classing it would be best. Of course, if you want to mine data from the client you’re going to have to write a wrapper around it.

Read full topic

[quote=“Jrekko, post:8, topic:398386”]Thanks for all the replies. Mitb has a good point. I was really only wondering to see if I could make a different bot, I don’t really care about actually cheating in the game so I wasn’t to worried if the bot couldn’t do much.

I might as well just use Java, I know the basics and it’s similar to C# so it shouldn’t be that much of a problem to learn.[/quote]
As you’ve said, C# and Java are pretty alike - so if you’re very familiar with one, picking up the other should be relatively easy.

item.title: A bot in C#?
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

[quote=“T4_, post:5, topic:398386”][quote author=Ollie link=topic=495521.msg3622863#msg3622863 date=1307586608]
you dont need a java bytecode editing library in c# to create a runescape bot. an updater prehaps. it’s totally possible to create a loader and push events using pure c#, you may need to find some reflection api to enable you to grab the client data though.
[/quote]
I suppose, but what would really be the point if you didn’t have an updater.[/quote]

the updater doesn’t need to be in c#

mitb puts a valid point, why c# when there is java available? and is infact more suited to the task in hand.

Read full topic

item.title: A bot in C#?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I’m sure there is probably a way to load the client into a C# form, although it will still have to run a JVM, and there is probably a way to push fake keyboard and mouse events to the client. The question here is how you plan on getting data from the client? You can’t easily modify it with C# code (no pre-written libraries, though you could roll your own), you certainly can’t perform reflection on the client in pure C#, without so much glue code written in Java (and probably C) that it would be much easier just to write the whole thing in Java. You can certainly react to colors and such, but then you might as well go with a pre-written solution like Simba.

So basically you need to ask yourself what exactly you wish to accomplish and why you want to write it in C#? If it’s because you know C# better, you will have to write enough Java code to learn it as well, so you might as well do the entire thing in Java, if it’s just to see if you can, go for it.

Read full topic

item.title: A bot in C#?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Ollie:

you dont need a java bytecode editing library in c# to create a runescape bot. an updater prehaps. it’s totally possible to create a loader and push events using pure c#, you may need to find some reflection api to enable you to grab the client data though.

I suppose, but what would really be the point if you didn’t have an updater.

Read full topic
